question.title: How do I create off heap Chronicle Value flyweight object?
question.body:
I am trying to use the Chronicle Values Java lib v2.23.3 to create an off-heap flyweights but I get this exception at runtime:

java.lang.AssertionError: cannot read/write 128 bits

I have set up 2 Value Interfaces following the syntax in the Use section of the github page as follows:

Header

public interface testMessageHeader {
@Group(0)
int val1();
void val1(int val1);

@Group(1)
int val2();
void val2(int val2);

@Group(2)
int val3();
void val3(int val3);

@Group(3)
int val4();
void val4(int val4);
}

Message

public interface testMessage{

enum MessageType {
    // some enums...


    private final int code;

    MessageType(int code) {
        this.code = code;
    }

    public int code() {
        return code;
    }

    public static MessageType fromCode(int code) {
        for (MessageType type : values()) {
            if (type.code == code) return type;
        }
        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unknown code: " + code);
    }
}

@Group(0)
testMessageHeader messageHeader();
void testMessageHeader (@NotNull testMessageHeader header);

@Group(1)
MessageType messageType();
void messageType(@NotNull MessageType type);

@Group(2)
long id();
void id(long id);

// Other primitive definitions...

@Group(15)
String getText();
void setText(@MaxUtf8Length(128) String text);

}

Initialization

In my code I am trying to create the flyweights in the following way

BytesStore hdrByteStore = BytesStore.nativeStore(16);
testMessageHeader header = Values.newNativeReference(testMessageHeader.class);
((Byteable) header).bytesStore(hdrByteStore, 0, hdrByteStore.length());
header.val1(16);

BytesStore msgBytesStore = BytesStore.nativeStore(1024);
testMessage msg = Values.newNativeReference(testMessage.class); // <-- Exception Generated here
((Byteable) msg).bytesStore(msgBytesStore, 0, msgBytesStore.length());

msg.messageHeader(header);
msg.messageType(testMessage.MessageType.<some type>);
msg.id(2);

Exception

The exception is generated at the indicated line above, with the full CV stacktrace being

 java.lang.AssertionError: cannot read/write 128 bits
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.IntegerFieldModel.integerBytesIoType(IntegerFieldModel.java:222)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.IntegerFieldModel.integerBytesMethodSuffix(IntegerFieldModel.java:208)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.IntegerFieldModel.read(IntegerFieldModel.java:204)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.IntegerFieldModel.genGet(IntegerFieldModel.java:307)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.IntegerFieldModel.genGet(IntegerFieldModel.java:296)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.IntegerBackedNativeMemberGenerator.generateGet(IntegerBackedNativeMemberGenerator.java:46)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.FieldModel.generateMethod(FieldModel.java:272)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.FieldModel.generateMembers(FieldModel.java:202)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.FieldModel.generateNativeMembers(FieldModel.java:193)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.Generators.lambda$generateNativeClass$0(Generators.java:44)
      at java.base/java.util.ArrayList$ArrayListSpliterator.forEachRemaining(ArrayList.java:1625)
      at java.base/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$Head.forEach(ReferencePipeline.java:762)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.Generators.generateNativeClass(Generators.java:44)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.ValueModel.createClass(ValueModel.java:324)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.ValueModel.createNativeClass(ValueModel.java:306)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.ValueModel.nativeClass(ValueModel.java:282)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.Values.nativeClassFor(Values.java:89)
      at net.openhft.chronicle.values.Values.newNativeReference(Values.java:57)

I imagine it's a simple thing that I've overlooked, but I'd appreciate any insight anyone can offer.

question_comments.body: As a follow up, in case anyone else runs into this issue, I managed to resolve the 128 bits error by modifying the messageType() signature to use ints as opposed to the enum.  I also needed to add @Align(offset = 8) annotations to all double fields to resolve field alignment errors
